instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Hi.

I have this board which is powering on but not showing picture. First i fixed flexgate just to make sure that it will run properly and since it's no picture issue of course no change. The laptop powers on fan spins and then just stays like that and it was not liquid damaged. Some time ago the client went to so called Apple official and they replaced the top case(keyboard housing) complete for no reason besides some keys pressing hard(probably from dust). Any ideas ?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Did you check for USB activity and external video?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: No external video and also no usb activity. <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> has voltage only on pin 3 and 4...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Then do not waste time expecting internal video.
Your board doesn't boot at all.
Turned on, is not the same with working board which has some particular problem.


Disconnect trackpad and any other flex, and check again for USB activity.
Do you note any variations on VCORE in the first 10-15s?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
"this board which is powering on
--------------------------
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0v"
I don't really understand; how is that possible???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
It was at a power on state probably something went off in the meantime. I'm not trying to take your time so please don't try to make fun out of what i wrote. I understand that you encounter many different ppl on the forum, but i really appreciate the support and would appreciate even more a bit more professional response. Thank you very much as always and once i fins time to measure all voltage i'll write back.

Have a good day

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Post the actual voltages you get on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: I have replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and that made a difference i got 20v on <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> but then <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> burned and i replaced it now also <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> was overheating and i replaced it also short is removed. Now i'm back at 5v and a short on <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> which came to be a short on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>. I removed <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> and now i'm stuck at 5v on the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Do i need both ports working ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: SMC needs to talk with both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: If i replace it from another board should be fine right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
If you replace with good chip only.
Also MUST have the same termination; like C00, B03, etc...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: yes same :) don't delay, buy today :ROFLMAO:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Staying on 5v on both ports after replacement of CD no short anywhere. Maybe i need to update firmware?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Do you get 1V1 LDO on the new chips?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Just got back to this board.  1V1 LDO no voltage. Also replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> again cause with he old one i was not even getting 5v on it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Would it make a difference if i don't have <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR> on the board cause it was shorted i had to remove it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: I know that on <CAPACITOR>C1170</CAPACITOR> should be low resistance but when i inject 1v on it pulls 1amps :D

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
Hi. Back on this board again.

i replaced both CD. I don't have 1v1 LDO on <CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Did you have 1V1 LDO on one port before?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: No i didn't. First the short was on one of the CD replaced it and it was stuck on 5v. Then shorted again on the other CD so i replaced both now i'm stuck at 5v no 1v1LDO on any of them

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> was burnt because of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> failure; no other reason possible.
That means overvoltage on <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Not worth to continue the repair on this board; possibly bad SMC, as CPU too...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a
threads.message: Thank you 2informaticos for your help  :cool:  happy Christmas
